title: GenAI Applied
description: Practical applications and real-world use cases of Generative AI
intro: This page focuses on using GenAI in the real world: spotting where it already shows up, deciding what to build, and integrating it into products and developer workflows.

sections.title: GitHub Copilot
sections.intro: GitHub Copilot is an AI pair programmer that provides real-time code suggestions, chat capabilities, and agent-based assistance directly in your development environment.
capabilities: Code completion: Suggests functions, code blocks, and entire implementations
Chat interface: Conversational help for reasoning about code and debugging
Multi-language support: Works across dozens of programming languages
Context awareness: Understands your repository structure and patterns

modes.name: Ask mode
modes.description: Best for explanations, exploring options, and quick checks

modes.name: Edit mode
modes.description: Best for refining existing code, documentation, and configuration files

modes.name: Agent mode
modes.description: Best for multi-step tasks where the AI plans and executes changes autonomously

customization: AGENTS.md: Agent-specific instructions for the coding agent
Custom agents: Define specialized agents with specific tools and behaviors

faq.question: When should I refactor using my IDE versus using Copilot?
faq.answer: Use IDE refactoring tools for standard operations like renaming symbols. Use Copilot for refactors that require understanding intent and cross-file reasoning.

faq.question: Which mode should I use for a complex feature implementation?
faq.answer: Start with Ask mode to discuss the approach, then use Agent mode for implementation, and Edit mode for refinements.

sections.title: Building Multi-Agent Systems
sections.intro: Multi-agent systems move beyond single 'do-everything' assistants to collaborative groups where each agent brings a specific skill.
whenToUse: Large workloads can be divided into smaller tasks for parallel processing
Complex tasks require distinct competencies (retrieval vs. code generation vs. review)
Separation of duties matters (policy checking, compliance review)
Different expertise is needed for different aspects of a task
Stronger isolation is required (running agents under least-privilege identities)

developmentPhases.name: Phase 1: Design (Low-Code)
developmentPhases.description: Use Microsoft Foundry Workflows to visually design agent orchestration with pre-built templates, node types, and Power Fx expressions for complex logic.

developmentPhases.name: Phase 2: Develop (Local SDLC)
developmentPhases.description: Use the Microsoft Foundry VS Code Extension to pull workflow definitions locally for debugging, testing, and integration.

developmentPhases.name: Phase 3: Deploy (Runtime)
developmentPhases.description: Microsoft Agent Framework natively ingests declarative workflow definitions (YAML) from Foundry for production deployment.

orchestrationPatterns.useCase: Tasks have dependencies and must run in order
Tasks are independent and can run in parallel
Multiple perspectives need to collaborate iteratively
Context determines which specialist should handle the work

designPrinciples: Make handoffs explicit: Define schemas that capture goal, inputs, constraints, evidence, and success criteria
Pass artifacts by reference: Use file IDs or links rather than copying full content
Bound execution: Set token/turn caps and clear exit conditions to prevent runaway loops
Log everything: Capture every handoff and tool call for traceability
Build evaluation harnesses: Exercise end-to-end scenarios to quantify quality

memory.description: Microsoft Foundry provides managed long-term memory that enables agents to retain and recall information across sessions.

types.description: Persistent information about users (name, preferences, dietary restrictions)

howItWorks: Extraction: Identifies key information from conversations
Consolidation: Merges similar memories and resolves conflicts
Retrieval: Hybrid search surfaces relevant memories when needed

sections.title: Monitoring and Evaluating AI Applications
sections.intro: Building AI applications is only half the challenge. You also need to monitor performance, evaluate quality, and ensure safety in production.
sections.whyItMatters: Without rigorous assessment, AI systems can produce outputs that are fabricated, irrelevant, harmful, or vulnerable to exploits.

activities: Test with evaluation datasets that simulate realistic user interactions
Identify edge cases where output quality might degrade
Measure key metrics like groundedness, relevance, coherence, and safety
Run AI red teaming to simulate adversarial attacks
Generate synthetic data if you lack real test data
Continuous evaluation: Sample production traffic and assess quality/safety
Scheduled evaluation: Run periodic tests with fixed datasets to detect drift
Operational metrics: Track latency, throughput, token consumption, error rates
Alerting: Set up notifications when metrics drop below thresholds

evaluatorTypes.measures: Groundedness, relevance, how well responses use retrieved context
Harmful content, bias, protected material, security vulnerabilities
Task adherence, task completion, tool call accuracy

azureSetup: Connect Application Insights to your Foundry project
Instrument tracing to capture detailed telemetry
Enable continuous evaluation to automatically assess production traffic
Use the dashboard to visualize metrics
Set up alerts for issue notifications

sections.title: The AI-Native Web: NLWeb, llms.txt, and Semantic Search
sections.intro: AI is changing how we navigate websites and data. Instead of clicking through menus and forms, we'll increasingly describe what we want in natural language.

concepts.name: Semantic search
concepts.description: Traditional search matches exact words. Semantic search matches meaning using embeddings (numeric representations of text).
useCases: Site search that understands synonyms and context
Cross-type discovery (e.g., 'the video that explains streaming tokens')

concepts.name: NLWeb (natural-language web)
concepts.description: Patterns that make the web conversational by default. Pages expose capabilities as structured affordances that AI agents can call.
changes: Interfaces become intent-first rather than page-first
Sites describe actions and data in machine-readable ways
Results include sources, links, and artifacts you can reuse
concepts.implementation: Open-source project that simplifies building conversational interfaces using semi-structured formats (Schema.org, RSS), vector stores, and MCP.

concepts.name: llms.txt
concepts.description: Like robots.txt for crawlers, a proposed convention for publishing an LLM-friendly index of a site.
concepts.details: A markdown file at /llms.txt that points to the most useful pages with summaries and optional 'nice to have' links.

sections.bottomLine: By adding llms.txt and shipping semantic search (or clean, machine-readable structure), you make your content easier for both people and agents to discover, cite, and reuse.
